subject: Re: [junit] debuggers
msgSnippet: A debug session is a manual testing session with implicit assertions made in the mind. If one captures those on paper, or in tests, then there is no need to
messageBody:
A debug session is a manual testing session with implicit assertions made in the mind.

If one captures those on paper, or in tests, then there is no need to re-do that debug session, or any other debug sessions "in the same class". (Loose definition. I think you understand what I mean.)

The more manual debug sessions captured in tests, the less need for manual debug sessions. Moreover, the few manual debug sessions you need deal with more intricate problems, and therefore give more return on investment.

If you have the discipline to turn EVERY debug session into at least one automated test, then over time, debugging can be made sufficiently obsolete.

Thanks.

So said steven.hale@... on 3/12/2003 --------------------

Does junit make debuggers obsolete? Are there situations where junit in
partnership with logging isn't sufficient?


Steven Hale
